<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
	<a id="top"></a>
	<div id="siteNotice" class="mw-body-content"><!-- CentralNotice --></div>
	<div class="mw-indicators mw-body-content">
</div>

	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Air-to-air rocket</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"></div>
		
		
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG/220px-Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG/330px-Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG/440px-Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Me_262_with_R4M_installation.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Me 262 with R4M underwing rockets</div></div></div>
<p><i>For air-to-air missiles, see <a href="/wiki/Air_to_air_missile" class="mw-redirect" title="Air to air missile">Air to air missile</a>.</i>
</p><p>An <b>air-to-air rocket</b> or <b>air interception rocket</b> is an unguided <a href="/wiki/Projectile" title="Projectile">projectile</a> fired from aircraft to engage other flying targets. They were used briefly in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> to engage enemy observation balloons and in and after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> to engage enemy bombers. Fighters were too maneuverable to be effectively engaged with rockets.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none" /><div class="toctitle" lang="en" dir="ltr"><h2>Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#History"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">History</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-2"><a href="#World_War_I"><span class="tocnumber">1.1</span> <span class="toctext">World War I</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-3"><a href="#Interwar_period"><span class="tocnumber">1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Interwar period</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-4"><a href="#World_War_II"><span class="tocnumber">1.3</span> <span class="toctext">World War II</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#List_of_air-to-air_rockets_by_country"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">List of air-to-air rockets by country</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>
</ul>
</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Air-to-air_rocket&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_I">World War I</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Air-to-air_rocket&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: World War I">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Rocket_(weapon)" title="Rocket (weapon)">Rockets</a> were used in World War I to engage <a href="/wiki/Observation_balloon" title="Observation balloon">observation balloons</a> and <a href="/wiki/Airship" title="Airship">airships</a>. Success rates were low and the rockets were dangerous to handle in the early fighters built from highly flammable materials.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup> By the end of the war they were replaced by the incendiary <a href="/wiki/Pomeroy_bullet" title="Pomeroy bullet">Pomeroy bullets</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> The Pomeroy bullet was developed to strike German <a href="/wiki/Zeppelin" title="Zeppelin">Zeppelin</a> airships, by igniting the hydrogen in the balloon. They did not always work.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">&#91;3&#93;</a></sup> One of the notable rockets from World War I was the <a href="/wiki/Le_Prieur_rocket" title="Le Prieur rocket">Le Prieur rocket</a> which had a range of about 115&#160;m (126&#160;yd), limited by inaccuracy. It was first used in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Verdun" title="Battle of Verdun">Battle of Verdun</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Interwar_period">Interwar period</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Air-to-air_rocket&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Interwar period">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The first known example of a successful attack of air-to-air rockets on another plane took place on August 20, 1939, during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Khalkhin_Gol" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Khalkhin Gol">Battle of Khalkhin Gol</a>. A group of Soviet <a href="/wiki/Polikarpov_I-16" title="Polikarpov I-16">Polikarpov I-16</a> fighters under command of Captain N. Zvonaryev successfully destroyed a few Japanese warplanes by launching of <a href="/wiki/RS-82_rocket" class="mw-redirect" title="RS-82 rocket">RS-82 rockets</a>. Soviet RS-82 rockets were mounted on special pylons under wings of Soviet fighters.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">&#91;4&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Air-to-air_rocket&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: World War II">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>Air-to-air rockets were utilized in World War II to engage <a href="/wiki/Bomber" title="Bomber">bombers</a> because cannon fire proved ineffective at high closing speeds. On top of that, getting in the range to fire one's guns also meant getting in the range of the bomber's <a href="/wiki/Tail_gunner" title="Tail gunner">tail gun</a>. The German <a href="/wiki/R4M" title="R4M">R4M</a> was the first practical rocket.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2010)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> It was highly successful, but came too late to change the outcome of the war.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2011)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> After experiencing the effectiveness of the German rockets, both the Soviet Union and the United States started developing their own.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (July 2011)">clarification needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>The invention of effective <a href="/wiki/Air-to-air_missile" title="Air-to-air missile">air-to-air missiles</a> spelled the end for their unguided counterparts in the 1950s. The capability of steering during the flight trajectory significantly increased the hit percentage over rockets. The United States built one last air-to-air rocket, the <a href="/wiki/AIR-2_Genie" title="AIR-2 Genie">AIR-2 Genie</a>. It used a <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_warhead" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear warhead">nuclear warhead</a> with a blast radius of 300m to compensate for its inaccuracy.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="List_of_air-to-air_rockets_by_country">List of air-to-air rockets by country</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Air-to-air_rocket&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: List of air-to-air rockets by country">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>France
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Le_Prieur_rocket" title="Le Prieur rocket">Le Prieur rocket</a></li></ul>
<p>Germany
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Nebelwerfer" title="Nebelwerfer">Nebelwerfer</a> derived <i><a href="/wiki/Werfer-Granate_21" title="Werfer-Granate 21">Werfer-Granate 21</a></i> (Wfr. Gr. 21)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/R4M_rocket" class="mw-redirect" title="R4M rocket">R4M rocket</a></li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=RZ.65_rocket&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="RZ.65 rocket (page does not exist)">RZ.65 rocket</a></li></ul>
<p>USA
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Fin-Folding_Aerial_Rocket" class="mw-redirect" title="Fin-Folding Aerial Rocket">Fin-Folding Aerial Rocket</a> (FFAR)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gimlet_(rocket)" title="Gimlet (rocket)">Gimlet (rocket)</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/AIR-2_Genie" title="AIR-2 Genie">AIR-2 Genie</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Zuni_(rocket)" title="Zuni (rocket)">Zuni (rocket)</a></li></ul>
<p>USSR
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/RS-82_rocket" class="mw-redirect" title="RS-82 rocket">RS-82</a> and RS-132</li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Air-to-air_rocket&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: References">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite id="Markowsky,_Perov" class="citation">Markovsky, K.; M. Perov (1994), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://epizodsspace.airbase.ru/bibl/kr/1994/10-nasledn.html"><bdi lang="ru">Наследники «ЭрЭсов»</bdi></a> (in Russian) (10) (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Wings_of_the_Motherland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wings of the Motherland (page does not exist)">Wings of the Motherland</a> ed.), Moscow, pp.&#160;21–23, <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0130-2701">0130-2701</a></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8+%C2%AB%D0%AD%D1%80%D0%AD%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B2%C2%BB&amp;rft.place=Moscow&amp;rft.pages=21-23&amp;rft.edition=Wings+of+the+Motherland&amp;rft.date=1994&amp;rft.issn=0130-2701&amp;rft.au=Markovsky%2C+K.&amp;rft.au=M.+Perov&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fepizodsspace.airbase.ru%2Fbibl%2Fkr%2F1994%2F10-nasledn.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AAir-to-air+rocket" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/><sup class="noprint Inline-Template"><span style="white-space: nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Link_rot" title="Wikipedia:Link rot"><span title="&#160;Dead link since June 2017">permanent dead link</span></a></i>&#93;</span></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div>
